text: Patient: It was in September, late September. Doctor: How are you? Patient: Doin’ good! Doctor: Uh, what’s goin’ on? Jaw still troubling you? Patient: A little bit, yeah. It’s, it’s, uh, right, right in, um in here. Right here. And the teeth are a little bit sensitive, just in spots Doctor: Gotten better or gotten worse? Patient: Um, it’s gotten better. Definitely gotten better. There’s still, uh, the little lump here, like a cyst. So, saw the ear, nose, and uh, throat specialist, and I have that right here where it’s drained. So, he gave me some ointment, um, prescription ointment that I put on every day, a couple times a day. Uh, I go back to see him in January, and you know, he just said, you know, to monitor it and make sure if anything gets worse to call him immediately. Doctor: And do they think this is related to the teeth or? Patient: They think so. Yeah. Doctor: Do you know how long you’ve had that lump? Patient: Um, uh, it started in, in August, late August. I, I, can see that it shrunk. I can see… Doctor: Did they say it’s smaller?

text: Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh. Family Member: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing. Doctor: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Right. Patient: Yeah, we’ll get into the pattern and we’ll just - Okay. Doctor: But, we’re not using, uh, uh a port. You know, we’re just going to use your regular vein. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we don’t combine Zytiga and the radium together. I specifically say that because there have been patients who have had leftover pills and yeah. Hey, the things going up after I try the pill. But actually, when they combined it people did worse so that study has already been done and people got more bone fractures so that’s no fun. So, I just tell everybody, you know, you’ve had it before. You can go on it after but not at the same time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s actually an absolute no-go black box. Okay, good. Family Member: What does the PSA going up, what does it, is it gonna cause it to spread? Doctor: It might really. No. But it might, again it’s not a reflection of what’s happening. It’s almost like oh, the ship’s sinking and the rats are all kind of jumping off. I’ve had patients that go from twenty to one hundred to five hundred and you’re like, oh, but they actually feel better. So, like it doesn’t match you. Family Member: It’s not the biggest thing because people always ask you what’s your PSA. Doctor: Yeah, no, just say oh, I’m on a treatment where the PSA actually goes up and like, you know, we have a vaccine therapy that that happens but Xofigo for sure and we know that because actually one of the fellows who is now faculty wrote a paper on our collective experience when we first started doing it and Patient: Alright. I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors.

I have something to run by you Doctor: Um hmm. Patient: with me going out of town and taking this. Would I be alright to travel? Doctor: Yeah. So, the good news is that we figured out that you will leave with a piece of paper after the radiation doctor gives you the injection because you will set off the TSA sensors.

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Sometimes longer than that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: At which point we’ll be transitioning to a different kind of treatment, hopefully. Doctor: Right. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: And, that’s the next discussion, what that is. And, that, that’s evolving, particularly for guys with your story. Family Member: Okay, so then you’re looking at like, like combinations of drugs? Doctor: Yeah. Normally, we would keep you on the hormone -- forever at that point, unfortunately. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And then, add things to them. Standardly, we would add another hormone, so you’d be on two. Research-wise, we would potentially consider these other drugs, particularly because of your mutation. Family Member: So, no chemo then? Doctor: No, not in, not in the short term.

text: Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Now it’s a bit misleading because it’s not truly zero. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s below the limit of detection, so the laboratory for example is below zero point one milligrams per ml. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: just says less than, the less than sign. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Zero point one. Doctor: We know that there is a very tiny, negligible microscopic level and say meaning that there are cancer cells left behind. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Family Member: I don’t know how you miss all that. Doctor: It would look like the needle would hit more. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: Do you want this. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
